summary: This document is an email chain from January 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing the drafting of a formal response to a request from civil plaintiffs' counsel (Robbie Kaplan) for information related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails coordinate the process for handling 'Touhy requests' for government information, designate a point person for such requests, and include draft legal language outlining the regulations governing disclosure.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney at Kaplan & Hecker representing civil plaintiffs/victims in lawsuits related to Jeffrey Epstein, to whom the U.S. Attorney's Office plans to send a formal letter outlining procedures for requesting information.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein Touhy Requests
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office staff discuss and agree on a process for handling future information requests from civil plaintiffs related to Jeffrey Epstein, designating a point person and planning to send a formal response to counsel.

events.title: Draft Letter to Kaplan Hecker
events.description: An initial draft letter is circulated among SDNY staff, intended to be sent to Robbie Kaplan, outlining the requirements for making a formal Touhy request for Epstein-related materials.

keyFacts: In early January 2020, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was coordinating its response to information requests from civil plaintiffs in Jeffrey Epstein-related lawsuits.
The office designated a specific Assistant U.S. Attorney as the point of contact to handle 'Touhy requests' for Epstein-related information from civil plaintiffs' counsel, notably Robbie Kaplan.

The correspondence includes detailed draft legal language explaining the stringent Department of Justice regulations (Touhy regulations) that govern the disclosure of information from criminal investigations for use in unrelated civil litigation.

The emails reveal an internal procedural separation, where criminal AUSAs would handle the investigative work, but a civil AUSA would manage external communications to avoid conflicts with victim-witnesses in ongoing criminal matters.
